case_vignette:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began 3 days ago. The pain is nonradiating and has no alleviating or exacerbating factors. He denies any nausea or vomiting. He immigrated from Mexico 6 months ago and currently works at a pet shop. He has been healthy except for 1 week of bloody diarrhea 5 months ago. He is 182 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 120 kg (264 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. He has tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.7 g/dL3
Leukocyte Count 14,000/mm
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 2%
Lymphocytes 17%
Monocytes 7%
Platelet count 140,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 139 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.4 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 8 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
AST 76 U/L
ALT 80 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 103 U/L
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 4-cm round, hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver with low-level internal echoes.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain in the upper right side of my belly that started 3 days ago.
Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting along with the pain?
No, I haven't had any nausea or vomiting.
Do you have a history of gallbladder issues or gallstones?
I've been healthy and don't have a history of gallbladder issues or gallstones, except for a week of bloody diarrhea 5 months ago.
Do you have any family history of gastrointestinal conditions?
I don't know about any family history of gastrointestinal conditions.
Are you currently taking any medications or supplements? If so, what are they?
I'm not taking any medications or supplements.
**Final Diagnosis:** Acute Cholecystitis
